introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.first: GuriVR is a free, open source project created to allow everybody to make Virtual Reality experiences with the lowest possible learning curve. The main tool that follows the goal is the online editor which is described below but Guri attempts to make the job easy in different ways. For example, it is possible to create a basic 360 panorama that works in the browser and with headsets like the Google Cardboard just by tweeting the picture with a mention to @guri_vr.
introduction.second: Guri is under active development and feedback is always welcome and under consideration for new features and bug reports. If you see something, say something üö® üëÆ

getting_started.title: Getting started
getting_started.first: The easiest way to learn how to use the editor is to play around with the sample scene located at the Homepage or create an account to be able to save your stories.
getting_started.second: The editor uses natural language processing techniques to interpret your words and convert the description into a VR experience. The ultimate goal for Guri is to be so intuitive you can express yourself using your own words without the need to think about it.

scenes.title: Scenes
scenes.first: Guri organize your stories into sequential scenes. Each scene is directly mapped with a paragraph in your description as soon as you specify the scene length.
scenes.second: You can create as many scenes as you want but don't forget about to set the duration in seconds.
scenes.third: Now that you know how to create scenes, let's see what kind of element you can add to your scenes:

entities.title: Entities
entities.first: A Guri scene is composed by a set of entities. A entity can be a 360 panorama, a videosphere, some text floating around, a 3d chart, images and more.
entities.second: Each kind of entity has modifiers (or attributes) associated. For example some elements can have a color, an asset or a determined position. For example, if I want a tiny picture of a pokemon at the left of the viewer I can express that to Guri using the following words:
entities.third: Below you can see the list of available entities and the modifiers that can be applied:

audio.title: Audio
audio.description: Audio source in the 3d space. It can be positioned in different parts of the scene. It needs a url as the source, the prefered format is mp3.

panorama.title: Panorama
panorama.description: 360 spherical image envolving the user view. It needs a url to display. It works better with equirectangular panoramas but works with any kind of images.

videosphere.title: Videosphere
videosphere.description: 360 spherical video envolving the user view. It needs a url to display. It works better with equirectangular videos but works with any kind of video.

image.title: Image
image.description: 2d images can be located inside the scene and placed in different positions.

video.title: Video
video.description: 2d videos can be located inside the scene and placed in different positions.

text.title: Text
text.description: You can write text and it will be displayed into the screen. There is no color or font support (it's just blank text for now)

duration.title: Duration
duration.description: You need to specify the duration of each scene in seconds. Otherwise it won't be displayed.

voiceover.title: Voiceover
voiceover.description: You can make your computer say phrases out loud. This will only work on browsers supporting speech synthesis.

chart.title: Chart
chart.description: Everything here is experimental but this feature really is. (In theory) you can create a chart on ChartBuilder, drag the json into the editor (or host it by yourself), and GuriVR will render it as a 3d chart. Give it a chance and if it don't work please raise an issue.

background.title: Background
background.description: You can change the boring black background on each scene with a cooler color.

3dmodel.title: 3D Models
3dmodel.description: Another <del>broken</del> experimental feature. You can insert Collada models into the scene.

sharing.title: Sharing
sharing.first: While logged in, you can save your stories and a share link is generated every time you save the story. This link can be shared as a standalone website or be embed into an iframe to be a part of a interactive piece.

share.title: Share it everywhere
share.description: GuriVR uses WebVR, the Web Open Standard for the Virtual Reality World. This works on modern web browsers, Google Cardboard and Oculus rift among others. It also fallback for desktop browsers using drag controls. You can share your experiences as standalone websites or inside your site as an iframe.

oss.title: Open source
oss.description: This is an open source project created as part of a Knight-Mozilla fellowship. You can contribute and/or propose ideas you have for this project. Note: A wise reporter once said "60% of the time it works every time". This tool is under development and you may find some bugs. In that case we will appreciate if you can fill an issue.
